Award.AwardTitle: Health Status of the Ecosystem, Biodiversity and Species Abundance along the Dakota Access Oil Pipeline.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Tribal Colleges and University Program is designed to support improvements in the science, math, engineering and technology (STEM) education and research capacities of colleges and universities that serve significant numbers of Native students in the United States. Strengthening these educational opportunities serves to increase the number of Indigenous people attaining STEM degrees and thereby diversify the STEM workforce in the United States. The Health Status of the Ecosystem, Biodiversity, Water, Soil and Species Abundance Along the Dakota Access Oil Pipeline project supports these outcomes through its study of the ecosystems surrounding the pipeline. Led by an expert interdisciplinary team of environmental science faculty members from Sitting Bull College on the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, the project focuses on gathering baseline data on species diversity, water quality, and soil characteristics of the areas on the reservation surrounding the pipeline. Faculty mentors also engage Native undergraduate and graduate students as integral members of the project, mentoring them in the design and conduct of the research and the presentation of its findings. The baseline information gathered in the study is an invaluable resource in helping further understanding of the environmental effects of pipelines over time and in formulating strategies for managing those effects. The ubiquitous presence of oil pipelines across the United States serving to meet the nation's energy needs makes this work highly relevant and significant to the American citizenry on a broad scale.

The focus of the Health Status of the Ecosystem, Biodiversity, Water, Soil and Species Abundance Along the Dakota Access Oil Pipeline is to conduct a baseline inventory of the species composition, water quality, and edaphic factors of various habitats surrounding the pipeline. Using sophisticated sampling techniques and state-of-the-art laboratory equipment, the project engages an interdisciplinary team of environmental scientists from Sitting Bull College in documenting, quantifying, and deriving relative abundance estimates of keystone species in the areas surrounding the pipeline on the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation. The comprehensiveness and rigor of the data collection and analyses enable the study of the ecosystem across spatial and temporal scales. These data will be widely available and will be valuable in furthering current understanding of pipeline impacts as well as informing future studies and the formulation of remediation plans for this and other pipelines in the United States. The collaboration of undergraduate and graduate level students with faculty mentors in the research design, implementation, and presentation contributes to the project?s broader impacts by developing the research capacity of the tribal college and its students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The effect of oil pollution on both aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems is documented, but there was no documentation on the species composition, water quality, and edaphic status of the study area. We built a baseline dataset for the study area to be used as a benchmark for future monitoring of changes in these habitats. The result narrows the gap in our understanding of the current diversity of life, river water quality, and both physical and chemical characteristics of soil in the Sioux Reservation Oil Pipeline Zone.

The area has fragile soils, low in moisture retention capacity. Overgrazing and low plant cover in most areas has exposed the soils to erosion and encroachment by prairie dogs. Mechanical analyses found 27% sandy loam, 25% silt loam, 37% loam, and 13% clay loam. We also did a soil nutrient analysis.

Water was sampled using the modified EPA Method 1664, equal-width-increment (EWI) sampling method, then tested for oil and grease presence, and the quantity recorded in grams per liter.  None of the samples from the Lake Oahe Reservoir had concentrations of oil and grease greater than 2.0 mg/liter for either sampling date.

For the vegetation survey, permanent main sample plots for tree study, and temporary nested plots for shrubs, herbs, grasses, and bryophytes study, were established along transect lines representing different habitats along the oil pipeline. They will be used to monitor any change in species composition or structure in all vegetation strata. The eighty-eight trees in the plots were of six different species: Populus deltoids, Ulmus americana, Acer negundo Fraxinus pennsylvanica, Quercus alba, and Juniperus virginiana. Noncommercial trees (small size, poor form, or inferior quality, unsuitable for industrial wood products) dominate the research area.

The mushroom survey found that of the 22 mushroom species found at the study area, 47% are edible, 19% have medicinal properties, 5% are hallucinogenic, 24% are poisonous, and 5% are homeopathic. All of the species belong to the phylum Basidiomycota. Some of the species encountered were Amanita daucipes, Bovista longispora and Clavulina cristata.

All but one of the streams had at least seven species of fish. The Notropis atherinoides made up the greatest percentage of the fish in the Grand River, Cannonball River, and Porcupine Creek, while the Notemigonus crysoleucas and the Pimephales promelas made up the largest percentage of fish in Oak Creek and Four Mile Creek, respectively. We also found that in the late spring, many fish species move up small tributaries in search of spawning areas and food.

The Myxomycete study found a statistically significant difference between the myxomycete diversity on bison dung and cow dung. The work was published in an international peer-reviewed journal (Journal of Bacteriology & Mycology Vol. 7 Issue 4-2019).

A total of 67 bird species and 2195 birds were counted during point count surveys. The most common species included Molothrus ater and Sturnella neglecta. Other species observed were, Fulica americana, Eremophila alpestris, Charadrius melodus, and Pheucticus ludovicianus. We noted that the Oahe Dam and Reservoir reduced sandbars, riparian wetlands/marshes, and total shore areas, impacting nesting habitat of shorebirds and waterfowl.

The analysis of forest conditions included an assessment of ability to sustain animal and environmental needs, along with species composition and forest disturbance, and the health is categorized as good. There were no windthrows, no major insect damage, no fire damage, and no diseases detected. The animal damage seen was negligible, i.e. throughout the survey, encountered only two 10 cm vertical debarking examples. The riparian forest was healthy and vigorously growing during spring. There was no natural threat to the forest trees, but glades are threatened by two invasive species, Euphorbia esula and Lonicera japonica.

We held a community engagement workshop on July 30th 2019 attended by over 30 participants. A student presented the oil and grease result at the 2019 Standing Rock Education Consortium Professional Development Day. Eight SBC students and two community members were trained on field data and sample collection, species identification, laboratory sample processing and testing, data analysis, and reporting. The project director attended a workshop on RNA and DNA sequencing and data analysis using MinION nanopore technology at Oxford Nanopore Technologies Center, New York. Ten STEM needy students benefited from scholarship money throughout the grant period and were able to continue with their education or successfully graduated. The four who graduated with BS degrees have all applied for the master’s program at SBC. New equipment and statistical software were purchased for the SBC science laboratory. Workshops and meetings provided information across departments and enhanced cooperation within departments.

The published work in peer-reviewed journals (attached) are a source of information for education and public awareness purposes. Hard copies of the publications and posters are available at the Sitting Bull College library for both public and student use.
